state.]] The 'ground state' of a quantum mechanical system is its lowest-energy
state; the energy of the ground state is known as the zero-point energy of the
system. An excited state is any state with energy greater than the ground state.
The ground state of a quantum field theory is usually called the vacuum state or
the vacuum.

If more than one ground state exists, they are said to be degenerate. Many
systems have degenerate ground states. It turns out that degeneracy occurs
whenever a nontrivial unitary operator commutes with the Hamiltonian of
the system.

According to the third law of thermodynamics, a system at absolute zero
temperature exists in its ground state; thus, its entropy is determined by the
degeneracy of the ground state. Many systems, such as a perfect crystal lattice,
have a unique ground state and therefore have zero entropy at absolute zero. It
is also possible for the highest excited state to have absolute zero temperature
for systems that exhibit negative temperature.
